Award.AwardTitle: Rocky Mountain Algebraic Combinatorics Seminar and Miniconferences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports travel for invited speakers and other participants in the Rocky Mountain Algebraic Combinatorics Seminar and associated mini-conferences. The seminar is held at Colorado State University on a biweekly basis. It provides a forum for researchers from Colorado State University, Colorado University at Denver, and the University of Wyoming to exchange ideas and present their research results. The annual mini-conferences are held on a rotating basis at one of the participating universities in the Rocky Mountain area.

Combinatorics is an area of mathematics that studies discrete structures. It is often a stepping-stone to applied disciplines such as Computer Science, Information Theory, and Engineering. As such, it is well suited to open up an important branch of academia to a broader audience, thus helping to foster STEM education. This meeting series not only advances research in algebraic combinatorics but also contributes to education in these important parts of science and technology. This award supports participation in the meetings by approximately ten speakers and student participants annually during the three-year period August 2014 through July 2017.

Seminar web site: www-math.ucdenver.edu/~wcherowi/algcomb.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Rocky Mountain Algebraic Combinatorics Seminar and Miniconferences" funded over a period of three years the following two major activities:


1) The seminar series "Rocky Mountain Algebraic Combinatorics Seminar", 

2) The international conference "Combinatorics and Computer Algebra -- CoCoA 15" (July 19-25, 2015).

 

Both activities took place at Colorado State University. The main objective of these activities is to continue to develop a vibrant community of researchers interested in Algebraic Combinatorics in the Northern Colorado region. In doing so, the project contributes to the education of a highly qualified workforce in the United States, both in industry and academics.

The activities related to the seminar series and to the conference directly impact on young researchers in many ways. The most important way is to provide a forum for exchange of ideas and for meeting like-minded people. This provides a stimulating environment for young researchers to grow and to become active members of the research community. The focus on algebraic methods and the associated connection to algorithms (as highlighted for instance in the title of the conference) shows the role that information technology plays in the kind of research that was funded through this proposal. It should also be noted that the conference CoCoA 15 funded a large number of young and very young researchers, many of which continue with a career path in algebraic combinatorics.

Summarizing, we are proud to say that the funds received through this grant have directly impacted the advancement of science and directly contributed to the education of many young researchers in the field of algebraic combinatorics.  

 


Last Modified: 07/19/2017
Modified by: Anton Betten
